column56: The ARC of Alachua County continues to pursue its 77% tobacco-free grounds policy. As of January the tobacco-free policy has been approved by the ARC board of directors. column56: B&B Office Systems has successfully implemented its 77% tobacco-free grounds policy as of January 1, 2014. Since the adoption of this policy, 1 B&B employee has successfully quit tobacco and a second employee is attempting to quit.

column56: Employer was going to see if staff or clients were interested in having cessation classes on sight.  Never responded to phone or e-mail messages.  1/3 employees on insurance plan.  11-14-2013 Phoned and sent flyer for AHEC classes. As yet, no interest in cessation classes.  Inquiry made to higher mgt. regarding e-cigs.  They had asked last year if there was a need for a policy change to include e-cigs but hadn't received an answer.  2-20-2014 Sent e-mail with flyer for next cessation classes.  Asked if there's any interest in having classes there.  No response.  4-10-2014 Spoke face to face about the possibility of having on-site classes for employees or residents.  4-16-2014 Sent flyer for classes and offered assistance.  6-16-2014 Sent flyer for July classes.  6-20-2014 Interacted with ma88ger at a community event.  6-24-2014 Ma88ger asked me to speak about our program at Rotary Club.
column57: Continue to send flyers about cessation classes.  Try to get a response about an on-site class.  2-20-2014 Continue to send flyers and stay in touch.  6-26-2014 Build on the relationship that is forming.

column56: 4-16-2014 Sent flyer for classes.  6-16-2014 Sent flyer for July classes and received a friendly response.  The flyers will be sent out with paychecks.
column57: Continue to send flyers about cessation classes.  11-14-2013 Continue to keep in touch and send flyers.  2-20-2014 Continue to send flyers for them to promote classes.  6-26-2014  Keep in touch about classes.

column56: Only 6 employees have the insurance.  It is very expensive and they had to get an exception to offer if for so few.  The smoke-free policies are enforced for employees but not clients.  Several employees use tobacco and flyers were posted for AHEC classes and TFF before I left. Tobacco Free Grounds signs were offered for posting but they have yet to accept.  11-14-2013 Phoned (not in).  Sent e-mail and flyer for next cessation classes.  No response.  2-20-2014  E-mailed flyer for upcoming cessation classes.  4-16-2014 and 6-16-2014 Sent e-mail with flyer about classes.  No response either time.
column57: 6-26-2014  No interest has been shown by employer but will continue to send info about classes.

column56: Participated in GAS last year and posted materials.  Aren't aware of any tobacco users.  No tobacco policies.  11-15-2013  Sent e-mail asking for update on any policies or benefits or any issues with e-cigs.  Sent AHEC flyers.  No response.  2-20-2014 Sent flyer for TTQ class on March 8.  Flyers sent on 4-16-2014 and 6-16-2014.
column57: Attempt contact to determine if any changes have been made regarding tobacco policies.  11-15-2013  Continue to send flyers.  2-20-2014 Never responds.  Continue to send flyers.  6-26-2014 Employer has shown no interest.

column56: No cessation benefits could be found when accessed online.  An insurance committee decides on the plan.  The 1 rep had referred the benefits person to check online.  She was surprised there were no cessation benefits and took flyers about AHEC classes and TFF to post.  10-14-2013 Attended SHAC meeting.  1 Rep was there presenting a wellness program.  Employees can earn up to $350 for completing health and wellness activities.  They have online and telephone coaching that uses best practices for Smoking Cessation (4 calls for telephone coaching and 5 weeks for online coaching)and say there are discounts for cessation products.  Sent flyers for AHEC classes and received response that they had been sent out.  2-20-2014 Sent flyer for TTQ class for March 8 and received response that it was being sent out.  Was contacted by a school health nurse who said she would give incentives to employees who attended cessation classes as part of their wellness plan. 4-16-2014 Sent flyers for classes. 5-15-2014 attended School Health Advisory meeting reports were given on the school employees Wellness Challenge.  1 gave a $10,000 grant which was used for incentives for participants.  They were given gift cards for completing challenges.  Three people quit smoking.  6-16-2014 Sent flyers for classes and received response that they were proud of their tobacco free employees and would distribute the flyers.
column57: Will be attending the School Health Advisory Council where the 1 rep will be presenting a new wellness plan.  Will question regarding cessation benefits.  11-14-2013  Will continue to send flyers.  2-20-2014 Continue to send flyers for promoting classes to employees.  6-26-2014 Keep sending flyers.

column56: 1 Rep sent links to specialty meds and a link to quitting tobacco that included articles about tobacco dangers, effects, developing a plan for tobacco cessation, and a list of resources to find support in quitting as well as quitlines.  In searching the meds, none were found to aid in cessation.  No mention was made of counseling sessions or covering costs in the resources.  The contact would like to have a policy for smoke-free vehicles. Flyers for cessation classes will be put in paychecks.  2-20-2014 Sent e-mail with flyer for TTQ class in March.  4-16-2014 and 6-16-2014flyers were sent for classes.  Asked about progress on tobacco free policies and the reply was that the budget was top priority  now but tobacco free policies would be kept on the list for discussion.  Also sent e-mail to the County Ma88ger asking him if they had considered adopting a tobacco free workplace.  The benefits were listed along with the costs of tobacco use.
column57: Continue to send flyers and inquire if any progress has been made toward smoke-free grounds or vehicles.  2-20-2014 Continue to send flyers to promote cessation classes. 6-26-2014 Keep in contact and continue info regarding classes.

column56: Research done prior to the meeting shows only an Online Health Coach:  Smoking Cessation Program.  The insurance has gotten very expensive.  TFF resources will be shared with employees.  HR Ma88ger was asked to consider a tobacco free workplace and bring it up to the insurance committee.  4-16-2014 and 6-16-2014 flyers for cessation classes were sent.  6-16-2016 sent e-mail to City Ma88ger asking if the City Council had considered adopting a tobacco free workplace.  He responded that they were considering it and how to implement it.
column57: Continue to send flyers.  6-26-2014 Build on relationship with City Council from the recent adoption of the flavored tobacco resolution.

column57: Further, Dr. Wells has included smoking cessation/tobacco elimi88tion as part of her wellness initiative for all DOH-Duval employees.  To demonstrate additio88l steps in that direction, she has offered her support to the Tobacco Prevention Program to arrange another smoking cessation class in quarter 2 to help a minimum of 20 employees quit tobacco.

This is one of the interviews conducted in FY 2012-13 that had not been uploaded for previous entry.  Staff pulled the notes from the Q1 ATACS report for that funding year.   interview was conducted by a previous TPS and staff was not able to access the actual Interview tool from the ATAC's System so this data is extracted from the notes she had on ATACS:  Tobacco prevention staff met with the Executive Director of the Florida Non-Profit
Housing Agency in Highlands to discuss the benefits of smoke free workplace policy and increasing employee cessation resources and referrals. The employer survey tool was utilized to help focus the conversation, collect data and information on this employer, and identify ways that staff could assist this employer. The Director was very interested and is sharing this information with his Board of Directors to discuss how they can support this goal area.
column57: Quarter 2:  Further follow up with this employer indicated they were not interested in any ECC services at this time; however the current TPS keeps this employer updated on SFMUH policies and will use that avenue to try to work with them on cessation benefits for employees as well.

column56: This is one of the interviews conducted in FY 2012-13 that had not been uploaded for previous entry.  Staff pulled the notes from the Q1 ATACS report for that funding year.   interview was conducted by a previous TPS and staff was not able to access the actual Interview tool from the ATAC's System so this data is extracted from the notes she had on ATACS: Tobacco prevention staff met with the President of the Greater Sebring Chamber of Commerce to discuss the benefits of smoke free workplace policy and increasing employee cessation resources and referrals. The employer survey tool was utilized to help focus the conversation and gain information on this employer. As a follow up, the President of the Chamber is sharing the information he learned at this meeting with his Board of Directors to discuss how they can better provide cessation resource to employees. Tobacco prevention staff will follow up to continue to provide assistance and other information.
column57: Quarter 2:  The Sebring Chamber continues to be a vital partner in the ECC Goal area by placing a link on the frontpage of their website so that business can click on "How to Become a Tobacco-Free Business".  This like takes them to information on smoke-free policy, cost savings, CDC recommendations for employee cessation benefits, 3 Way to Quit, and local TPS contact information.  Current staff worsk very closely with this Chamber, and their business members, every quarter to encourage employers and employes on the best ways to access to cessation services and benefits.

column56: This is one of the interviews conducted in FY 2012-13 that had not been uploaded for previous entry.  Staff pulled the notes from the Q1 ATACS report for that funding year.   interview was conducted by a previous TPS and staff was not able to access the actual Interview tool from the ATAC's System so this data is extracted from the notes she had on ATACS: On 11/27/2012, Quit Doc tobacco prevention staff conducted a Employee Benefits survey with the owners of Highway Park Liquors. This is a minority owned business and they employ two full-time and six part-time employees and they only offer a stipend to the full-time employees to apply towards health insurance. As a result of the survey, the Tobacco Prevention Specialist was invited to give a presentation on the Benefits of a Smoke-free Workplace. During this meeting the owners disclosed that, because their business is a local bar, they do not feel that implementing a smoke-free policy is feasible. However, they were opened to hearing more about available tobacco cessation resources.
column57: Quarter 2:  Further follow up with this employer indicated they were not interested in any ECC services at this time.

column56: This is one of the interviews conducted in FY 2012-13 that had not been uploaded for previous entry.  Staff pulled the notes from the Q1 ATACS report for that funding year.   interview was conducted by a previous TPS and staff was not able to access the actual Interview tool from the ATAC's System so this data is extracted from the notes she had on ATACS: On May 30, 2013 Quit Doc staff conducted an interview with Andrew Bible of Heartland 88tio88l Bank. Staff used the BTFF Tobacco Cessation Benefit Summary Survey to complete this interview. During this interview, Mr. Bible confirmed that this is a for-profit business and they do hire tobacco users. Employees are allowed to take short breaks and are allowed to use tobacco products during this time. However, they are not permitted to use tobacco products in company vehicles and they do not have a Tobacco-Free grounds policy, but the interior of the banks are tobacco-free and employees are encouraged to not use entry ways to smoke. According to Mr. Bible, 41 of Florida (41) is the company's insurance provider and their policy does not offer cessation services, but 41 does encourage employees  to live healthier lifestyles through a benefits newsletter. Employees are not offered any cessation services nor are fi88ncial incentives used to promote tobacco cessation.
column57: Initial notes:Employees are not offered any cessation services nor are fi88ncial incentives used to promote tobacco cessation. Quarter 3 notes: Staff dropped off materials and left contact information with Mr. Bible. Q4: No change in status.

The insurance provider for the health care facility is 41 and the company's policy

column57: This employer fully embraces promoting the 3 Ways to Quit for his employees. He consistently encourages smokers to quit by posting AHEC class information every 6 weeks. There was no new action taken by the employer in Q4.

column56: The TFP will participate in the Employee Health Fair on June 27, 2014. No other changes in Q4. The HR Administrator distributes Three Ways to Quit to all employees every 6 weeks. There are no  desig88ted smoking areas on the main county campus or an employee policy on tobacco. Employees are encourage to quit using Three Ways to Quit info and AHEC Tobacco Class Flyers at the HR office. Information is emailed to all employees. There is no employee manual, therefor there is no tobacco use policy and no policy about smoking on campus other than adhering to the FL Clean Indoor Air Act. The Attorney states pre-emption overides their authority as employers to dictate a smoke free workplace.
column57: The HR Administrator and Wellness Committee planned to develop an employee tobacco cessation policy without having a tobacco free workplace policy, but this has not yet happened. It is not certain where this policy will reside (outside of the HR Office) since there is no Employee Manual. There was no action taken by the Employer in Quarter 4.

column56: No change in Q4 2013-14. Q3 follow up revealed an unintended consequence of becoming a 77% TFG. Employees leaving the grounds to smoke became a safety hazard. Now employees smoke in their cars on the grounds. 3 Ways to Quit. AHEC Quit Smoking Now classes are ongoing at this employer's location. Wellness Committee is including tobacco cessation as part of their healthy choices for a healthy lifestyle.
column57: The TFG plan is being implemented with employees smoking in cars rather than off campus due to safety concerns.

column56: This employer successfully implemented a Tobacco Free Campus and has instituted the Three Ways to Quit at their workplace. Most smokers are not eligible for health benefits, so changing health benefits to cover cessation is not an option at this time.
column57: SRA is in stage 4 this quarter. They have written policy to institutio88lize cessation benefits not covered by health insurance; i.e. promoting all community cessation classes,  3 Ways to Quit and providing cessatio benefits at no cost to the employee. The majority of employees using tobacco are part time and not eligible for health insurance benefits.

column56: We are active members in the School District Employee Health and Wellness Committee and they are active members of the Partnership. There continues to be dialogue about what the county is doing to promote cessation resources to their employees. Currently, 60% of schools in Pasco County allow their employees to smoke on campus. The Teachers' Union contract says that every school built prior to 1996 has to vote on going tobacco free, and if even one teacher wants to retain their right to smoke at school, the vote will not pass. There is a proposal by the superintendent and SWAT to negotiate this contract to reflect the majority of employees' opinions.

column56: Tobacco Prevention Consultant had made follow up phone calls. HR Ma88ger was very passio88te on getting a smoke-free policy.  HR Ma88ger is still waiting for two owners to make decision on Smoke-Free Policy.
column57: HR Ma88ger had a meeting with the two owners and shared with them about a smoke-free policy and E-Cigarettes in the work place.  The two owners shared their concerns that they might lose good employees if they start implement a smoke-free policy.  The positive outcome of the meeting is that the two owners did stated that they will think about the smoke-free policy over the holiday and get back with HR Ma88ger.  HR Ma88ger shared with TPC that this was the first time the two owners got together and talked about a smoke-free policy.

column56: Tobacco Prevention Consultant had made follow up phone calls.  Store Ma88ger still waiting for store owner to make decision on Smoke-Free Policy.  Store Ma88ger said that the owner is 50-50 on deciding whether he should have a Smoke-Free Policy or not.
column57: Store Ma88ger is still waiting for the store owner to make a decision on adopting a smoke-free policy.  Store Ma88ger still positive that the store owner will adopt a smoke-free policy eventually.  Store owner shared his concerns that he might lose good employees if he implement a smoke-free policy.

column56: Tobacco Prevention Consultant spoke to  Store Ma88ger about Smoke-Free Policy.  Currently, Family Dollar does not have a Smoke-Free Policy for its employees.  However, Store Ma88ger stated that Corporate Office will implement a Smoke-Free Policy for all Family Dollars' employees as of January 1, 2014.  All employees cannot smoke on property during working hours.  Also employees that do smoke, will have to pay an extra $77 on their insurance premium
column57: Tobacco Prevention Consultant will continue to do follow up phone calls in one month.  Store Ma88ger will try to get a copy of the policy in January 1, 2014 and will keep Tobacco Prevention Consultant update.

column56: Tobacco Prevention Consultant met with store owner and discussed about a Smoke-Free Policy.  Owner was not aware of Cessation Class offer at the local health department.  Owner stated that his employees buy their own insurance.  Store owner stated that 4 out of 5 employees smoke but do so outside away from the door.  The owner said he was thinking about implement a Smoke-Free Policy for all his employees because he had complaints from customers saying that they can smell his employees' breathe from smoking.  Store owner said he let Tobacco Prevention Consultant know whether he will enforce a Smoke-Free Policy or not.
column57: Tobacco Prevention Consultant will do follow phone calls in two months to see if store owner has made up  his mind about adopting a Smoke-Free Policy.

column56: Tobacco Prevention Consultant met with store ma88ger to see if Tom Thumb store have a smoke-free policy and if not, would want one.  As right now, corporate office has not made a decision on smoke-free policy yet.  TPC will do follow up phone calls and visits within two months.

Tobacco Prevention Consultant met with store ma88ger to see if Lowe's store have a smoke-free policy and if not, would want one.  Lowe's does have a 77% TFG policy for all of their employees.  TPC will do follow up phone calls and visits within two months trying to get a copy of the smoke-free policy.
column57: Tobacco Prevention Consultant continue to work with Store Ma88ger in trying to obtain  a copy of the Lowe's smoke-free policy from Corporate Office but with no success.  Also, TPC will continue to work with Store Ma88ger in offering tobacco cessation classes to Lowe's employees that are trying to quit smoking.

column56: Tobacco Prevention Consultant met with SRHRC Administrator to see if SRHRC has a smoke-free policy and if not, would want one.  As right now, corporate office has not made a decision on smoke-free policy yet.
column57: Tobacco Prevention Consultant has been meeting with SRHRC Administrator on a monthly base to try to work on a smoke-free policy for his employees. TPC and AHEC had provided two outreach at the SRHRC for their staff and provided 2 cessation classes so far.  TPC has made phone calls and do re-visits montly. As right now, there are 12 out of 24 employees who smoke had attended the smoking cessation classes provided by AHEC along with TPC.  There are 24 SRHRC businesses within the State of Florida.  TPC and SRHRC Administrator hope that by develope a smoke-free policy at his location, the other 23 locations will follow.  TPC will continue to work and re-visit SRHRC on a  montly base.

column56: Tobacco Prevention Consultant met with Avalex HR Ma88ger to see if Avalex has a smoke-free policy and if not, would want one.  As right now, Avalex has does not have smoke-free policy yet.
column57: Tobacco Prevention Consultant had met with Avalex HR Ma88ger on a re-visited and see where she stands.  TPC had provided one outreach at the Avalex for their staff and waiting for a date to come back for tobacco cessation class.  TPC has been in contact with Avalex HR Ma88ger on a montly bases.  As of right now, Avalex's employees are in insurance registration period and that the HR Ma88ger had asked the TPC to come back in 2 months once the registration period is over.  So far, there only 6 Avalex's employees have registered to attend the cessation class.  TPC was hoping that there would be more sign up by the time insurance registration is over.  There are about 12 employees who smoke but did not sign up for the cessation class.

column57: 5/13/14- Met with the Human Resources Ma88ger, Roxanne Bliss.
